intro: Sambucus pubescens f. dimidiata, commonly known as the dwarf elderberry, is a compact shrub native to the eastern United States. It features small, dark green leaves that are oval to heart-shaped with serrated edges. The plant produces clusters of small, white flowers in early summer, which are followed by edible, dark purple berries in the fall. Its botanical characteristics include hairy stems and leaves, giving it a distinctive textured appearance. It is often cultivated for ornamental purposes due to its attractive foliage and seasonal interest.
